Glo does not give medical advice or engage in the practice of medicine.

title: Build Strength and Confidence for Arm Balances
description: Developing your core, shoulder and arm strength establishes confidence and skill in arm balances and inversions. Strengthen your body where you need it the most for these postures: your abdominals, hip flexors, shoulders and arms. You will tackle a few arm balances, but focus more on strengthening postures that will build your skill and confidence for arm balances in the future. Props Needed: A block.

title: Continuous, Breath-Centered Flow
description: You have arrived at the heart of vinyasa yoga. Synchronize breath and movement from the beginning to the end of class with continuous, rhythmic motion in tune with slow deep breathing. Glide through salutations, standing poses, backbends and several arm balances including vashistasana and crane variations. Think of this as a moving pranayama practice.

title: Move Your Practice Forward
description: Stuck in a yoga rut? A challenging practice that will move it forward by tackling less common posture variations. Integrate handstand work into your sequence, explore less common backbends and arm balances and work on binds and twists. Move at a steady, mindful pace that will keep you moving, but won't feel rushed. If it's time to do something just different enough, then this one's for you.

title: Yoga Fusion for Your Hips
description: This hybrid practice incorporates strengthening the hip muscles using an optional resistance band, plus a balanced yoga sequence for healthy mobility. Begin with basic hip work including utkatasana squats and clamshells, then build off of traditional sun salutations. With a balance of stretching and toning, this class provides optimal functional yoga for your hips. Props Suggested: A resistance band.

title: Every Day, Go-To Flow
description: A strong, thorough flow practice that includes a little bit of everything. Designed to be a class that you come back to time and time again, your practice includes hip openers, salutations, standing pose flows, inversions and backbends. This class is at a slightly quicker pace than most of my classes. Feel complete and appreciate your body's ability to move and breathe with power and intention. Props Needed: Wall space.

title: Lotus & The Splits
description: For everyone that finds lotus and splits challenging and elusive, but wants to take baby steps toward these key postures. You'll unwind tension in your hamstrings, outer hips, quadriceps and hip flexors in a wide range of postures. Do core strengthening work to help stabilize the motion of your lower back, which sometimes compensates for restriction in the hips. Enjoy making headway in these postures. Props Needed: A block and a strap.

title: Hip-Opening, Arm-Balancing Flow
description: This is a straightforward vinyasa practice that will open your hips and deepen your arm-balances. The practice begins with a few minutes of hip-openers and progresses into a strong, continuous flow that includes plenty of arm balances. You'll feel satisfied when its over but you might not want savasana to end.

title: Core for Beginners
description: A quick, complete core practice designed for new students and teachers that work with new students. It contains accessible postures that will strengthen your abdominals, inner-legs and thighs. These postures help trim your midsection and lay the foundation for more challenging work in the future. The practice is also suitable for more experienced students that want a slightly lighter core practice. Props Needed: A block.

title: Yin/Yang for your Spine
description: This practice will improve range of motion in your spine through a combination of active and passive asanas. You'll begin with a 30-minute flow of postures including forward bends, twists, side-bends and backbends. You'll complete the practice with nurturing, grounding, passively held postures that will release tension throughout your entire spine. Props Suggested: Two blocks and a blanket.

title: Strong, Non-Stop Flow
description: I don't teach fast classes, but this one is strong and continuous. Minimal instruction, continuous motion punctuated by a few longer holds and several key arm-balances. Class includes starting in handstand, plenty of standing posture transitions, inversion variations and a savasana that you'll never want to end. Props Suggested: Wall space.

title: Optimal Conditioning for Your Core
description: Methodically strengthen your entire core with this hybrid practice of yoga and resistance band work. Learn exactly what your core is while creating greater stability and control in your center as you flow through crescents with lateral pull downs, forearm planks with arm raises, and camel lean backs. Props Suggested: A resistance band.

title: Working with Seriously Stiff Shoulders
description: This practice is designed for students with seriously stiff shoulders. The sequence includes accessible postures that will help you restore range of motion and facilitate circulation. It includes a combination of chair work, standing and reclined postures. Props Needed: Strap and chair. The information contained on Glo's website is of a general nature and cannot be a substitute for the advice of a medical professional. We urge you to consult with a physician or other health care professional before engaging in any physical activity, regimen, routine, program or exercise that may be presented in these materials. Glo does not give medical advice or engage in the practice of medicine.

title: Awaken Your Entire Body
description: If you want a strong, quick flow practice that will awaken your entire body, this is your class. This practice will get your blood moving and help you stay focused through your day. You'll kick off practice with a few spinal lengtheners, transition into a steady stream of salutations, standing poses, and peak with Urdhva Dhanurasana. This practice provides minimal instruction so that you can have some peace and quiet while you move your body.

title: No Chaturanga Flow
description: Want a nice, balanced flow class without chaturanga? Maybe you need to give your shoulders and wrists a break, or you are just tired of working on this pose ad-nauseam. This complete, balanced practice will awaken and strengthen your entire body without ever including chaturanga. You will move, breathe and explore the many options that will teach you to do a satisfying vinyasa practice without its most infamous posture. Props Suggested: A block.

title: Inner Leg Strength and Flexibility
description: This practice will create greater strength and flexibility in your inner leg muscles (adductors). This often ignored, challenging-to-access region is explored in reclined core-work, unique standing postures, lunges, and seated work. It will leave you feeling more grounded and spacious -- the perfect complement to Jason's other classes that focus on the IT band and glutes. Props: Block, Wall Space

title: Quick, Go-To Flow
description: Short on time and want a strong, thorough practice? This sequence includes hip-openers, standing poses, surya namaskar, twists, inversions and more. It's got a bit of everything you need without being rushed or overwrought. This balanced, complete sequence will get you through your day (each and every day you need it). Prop suggested: Wall space

title: Core-Strengthening for Wimps
description: Core work can be intimidating to those that need it most. While challenging at times, this practice is designed for students that need more strength and awareness in their center but need a little more time and support. You will discover how to strengthen your center in a patient and sustainable way. This class also includes plenty of standing postures, twists, lunges and other groups that will sweeten the deal. Props Needed: One block.

title: Balanced, Accessible Practice
description: Designed for new students, and others that want to revisit the basics, this practice will stretch and strengthen your entire body. You will work on essentials such as downward-facing dog, cat/cow, and standing postures. This practice will leave you feeling more comfortable and confident in your body. Optional Props: Block, chair, blanket

title: Strengthen Your Abdominals, Open Your Hips
description: Straightforward and to the point, this practice will strengthen your abdominals and stretch your outer hips. These two focal points complement each other by providing your hips and lower back with greater strength and mobility. You'll do focused abdominal strengthening and creative hip-opening in the context of a full-body vinyasa practice. Props Suggested: A block.

title: Set the Tone for the New Year
description: This all-around, whole-body practice will set the tone for the New Year. While encouraging you to be mindful of your intentions for the new year, move through hip-openers, salutations, standing poses, inversions, backbends and arm-balances. Connect to the deepest reasons you practice yoga. Props Suggested: Wall space.

title: For Burnt Out Yoga Teachers
description: All teachers get burnt out from time to time. This practice will help you work with this state of stress and fatigue in a way that is soothing and grounding. Wring out tension with easy twists, go inward with forward folds, and restore calm energy with time upside down in headstand and a lengthy supported legs up the wall. Props Needed:  A bolster, a block, and wall space.

title: Strong, Fluid, and Flexible
description: This strong, continuous flow will focus on strengthening the entire backside of the body, while lengthening the front. Begin with sun salutations to warm up, then continue to flow through crescents, warrior variations, one-legged down dog to one-legged planks, and an option to arm balance. Continue to develop balanced length and strength with backbends, then cool down before a final savasana.

title: Restore Your Posture
description: This mellow, prop-intensive practice will help release stress and tension from your chest, upper back, and shoulders. Gradually spread relief down your spine, beginning with a blanket rolled under your shoulders, then working your way to your lower back. Roll onto your belly to get into the back of your chest and shoulders, then relax into a twist with your bolster to support you. Props Needed: A blanket and a bolster.

title: Straight-up Flow
description: Strong, continuous and unrushed, this straightforward flow will get your blood moving. It's exactly what you'd expect - and want - a vinyasa practice to be. Includes poses like visvamitrasana, eka pada galavasana, ustrasana, and urdhva dhanurasana.

title: Strengthen Hamstrings, Stretch Quads
description: Most asana practices include an abundance of hamstring stretching and very little hamstring strengthening. Conversely, most practices do several postures that strengthen the quadriceps and few that stretch the quadriceps. This sequence flips these roles by emphasizing postures that strengthen the hamstrings and stretch the quadriceps. In addition to benefiting regular asana practitioners, this class will be particularly helpful to runners.

title: Practice for New(ish) Parents
description: This class for new(ish) parents (and everyone else that is madly in love, is oh-so tired and whose shoulders and back are killing them) I filmed this class 6-months (to the day) after my daughter was born. It was done in pure self-interest to help my shoulders, neck, upper-back and hip-flexors feel less terrible. If you are new(ish) parent - or are madly in love with someone or something else - and your shoulders, neck, upper-back, and hip-flexors are paying the price (and, youâ€™re starting to get out of shape), this one is for you. Props Recommended: Strap and Blanket

title: Psoas Strength and Flexibility Flow
description: Balanced strength and flexibility of the psoas is essential for hip and spine health. This dynamic practice focuses on deep psoas strengthening and stretching in sun salutations, low lunges, standing postures, core strengtheners and arm-balances.

title: Yin/Yang for Hips
description: Start with a 15 minute yin sequence that opens the front of your hips, thighs and anterior spine. Next, begin a challenging 30 minute, nonstop flow that emphasizes hip and hamstring opening. Post movement, wind down with a yin sequence that releases tension in your outer/posterior hips. If you're looking for a combination of deep, slow openers and a strong, steady practice, look no further.

title: Balanced Strength and Flexibility
description: Explore the value of both active and passive ranges of motion. This well-rounded practice is focused on creating balanced strength and flexibility throughout your entire body. You'll warm up with sun salutations; play with balance in tree, dancer pose, and half moon variations; and then get some air time in parsva bakasana and eka pada koundinyasana 1. There'll be plenty of time to wind down and stretch out the hips, with a nice, long savasana to round things out.

title: Backbend Fundamentals
description: This practice will teach you the fundamentals of backbending by focusing on creating a deeper, safer urdhva dhanurasana (upward facing bow, or wheel pose). You will learn how opening your upper-back--not your chest--may be the key to unlocking greater space, freedom and integrity in this pose. Of course, you will also learn how to prepare your legs, hips and spine for this essential, majestic posture. Prop: 1 block

title: Give Your Wrists a Break
description: Back by popular demand and even longer than the last! This 45-minute practice will take you through a strong, satisfying vinyasa series without bearing any weight on your wrists. Use dynamic transitions that power up your core as you play with sun salutations, and work forward folds and twists to balance your body out. If you've been wanting a strong practice and you're giving your wrists a break, this is tailor-made for you.

title: Slow and Steady Flow
description: This is a deceptively challenging flow practice. The mindful, slow pace will allow you to focus on your breath and help you build strength in your entire body. If your looking for a grounding, demanding practice without too much complexity, look no further. Touch upon every major muscle group, get sweaty and cool off before taking a nice savasana. Walk away feeling strong, grounded and at ease.

title: Full Body Flow
description: Get ready to practice your new go-to flow! This active, all-around sequence moves you through lunges, standing balances, core work, hip openers, forward folds and backbends. Begin with sun salutations, adding anjaneyasana, navasana and natarajasana into your sequencing, then flow into standing forward bends, pigeon variations and urdhva dhanurasana, before cooling down with savasana. Enhance your energy, strength, and commitment to your practice with this extended class.

title: The Essentials of Binding
description: Learn the essential techniques of binding postures with this hip and shoulder-opening practice. Learn how to prepare your hips, shoulders and spine in order to make binding more accessible. Explore standing binds, seated forward fold binds, and seated twists with binds. And, hey, if nothing else, you will get a thorough stretch in some of the areas that need it the most! You may need a belt for this practice if binding is difficult for you.

title: Strengthening the Entire Body
description: This practice will strengthen all the major muscle groups of your body. You will proceed from bottom to top, beginning with your calves and hamstrings and concluding with your upper back and arms. The sequence includes all the usual suspects: sun salutations, standing postures, arm balances, core strengtheners, backbends and more. Props Needed: Wall space and a block.

title: Shoulder, Upper Back, Neck Flow
description:
This practice will provide your shoulders, neck and upper-back with greater strength and flexibility. The dynamic sequence includes detailed shoulder openers, modified sun salutations and standing poses, inversions and seated postures that will make your upper body feel oh so good.

Props needed: Wall Space

title: Revolved Triangle Practice
description: Letâ€™s face it, revolved triangle is really hard for most students. Sure, it has a big payoff for your hamstrings, hips, IT band, spine, abdomen and shoulders. But, thatâ€™s exactly why itâ€™s such a challenging and often unbalanced posture, because it combats tension in all of these regions simultaneously. Fortunately, this practice is designed to help open all of these regions and provide you with some essentials tricks to make this big pose more accessible. Props Needed: A block, a strap and wall space.

title: Core TLC
description: Oh the poor core! It's becoming the rented mule of our body in contemporary yoga practice. Sure, it's important to strengthen the region, just like it's important to strengthen all of the regions of the body, but this area needs some TLC too. This practice will help you let go of deep-seated tension in your core by giving you permission to let go, breathe, and relax. Tune in, it will feel good. Props Needed: One or two blankets.

title: Yin & Yang
description: A balanced Yin and Yang practice that has three segments: A 15-minute opening yin component, a 30-minute strong yang component, and a 15-minute grounding, closing yin component. You'll do a little bit of everything, and a lot of a few things. This is a uniquely styled class that will touch upon all major muscle groups, where the goal is to feel great while doing and after practicing.

title: Focus On What You Need Most
description: This practice is designed to do 2 things: Give you a thorough, balanced practice and teach you how do mini-sequences that allow you to focus on the parts of your body that need it the most. The concept is simple: you will do 4 hip-opening lunges, 4 shoulders openers, 4 different styles of sun salutations, 2 groups of 4 standing poses, 4 backbends, 4 forward bends and 4 twists. By organizing the class this way, you'll have a great, balanced practice and be able to learn whichever mini-sequences are right for your body. Prop: 1 block

title: Feel Good Flow
description: This feel good flow focuses on opening your quads, hip-flexors, chest, and shoulders. You'll unwind tension in your front body and psoas with deep low lunges, high lunge variations, and backbends. Complement this work with standing posture variations that focus on releasing your chest and shoulders. Take a few supine twists and a hip opener before resting in savasana. Move every part of your body and walk away feeling accomplished and satisfied.

title: Feel Good Flow with Sidebends
description: This dynamic vinyasa practices focuses on opening your side-body from the IT band and outer hips to the obliques and lats. It begins with a few slow, deep outer hip-opening postures before moving into an all-around vinaysa practice that emphasizes lateral flextion. The practice concludes with seated postures that will unravel tension in the side-seam of your entire body.

title: IT Band Relief
description: Notorious and misunderstood, the IT band is one of the most frequently requested topics from my students. This practice focuses on relieving tension in the iliotibial band by stretching the IT band and the primary muscles that put tension on IT bands; the outer-hips and quadriceps. You'll also learn about your IT's form and function and put the region in perspective. Props Needed: A strap. Props Suggested: A block.

title: Arm Balances, Backbends and Inversions
description: This is a straightforward, demanding vinyasa flow. It begins with a few minutes of deep hip-opening and progresses into a steady-stream of arm-balances and inversions. It concludes with big, full backbends.

title: Quench Your Quads
description: Quadriceps calling for a good, deep stretch? Work your quads with a short sequence that helps strengthen and lengthen your leg muscles. Begin with a standing stretch at the wall, then move on to your mat for lunge variations and downward dog. Props Suggested: Wall space.

title: Engaging Your Glutes
description: An educational class on how and why it’s crucial to utilize the glutes in your practice to prevent injury, improve form, and perfect your backbends.

title: The Five Movements of the Spine
description: This flow practice focuses on the five movements of the spine. It's designed to keep the spine healthy, balanced and supple and clarify your understanding of these 5 essential spinal movements. The sequence includes a bit of everything including sun salutations, standing poses, side-bends, forward bends, backbends, and twists. Think of it as a back-care practice for students that are fortunate enough to not have any back-pain!

title: Sensitive Shoulder and Wrist Practice
description: Working with shoulder and wrist challenges that limit weight bearing can be difficult and frustrating; especially for students that like a more rhythmic, flowing class. If you (or your students) fit this category, this practice is designed for you. This dynamic practice includes abdominal work, standing poses, and innovative sun-salutations that minimizes impact on your upper-body.

title: Sustainable, Rhythmic, Continuous Movement
description: This strong, continuous flow focuses on sustainable, rhythmic breathing as you glide from one posture to another. You'll get to listen to breathing cues and drop deeply into a strong, continuous practice that features a little bit of everything. A must-do for those of you who resonate with fewer postural instructions and more continuous movement.

title: Grounding & Centering with Hip Openers
description: Deeply soothing, grounding, and centering, this unhurried practice will unwind your hips and calm your mind. The vast majority of the practice stays low to the ground, featuring more than enough seated hip-openers, forward bends and twists. The practice will also help you release tension from your abdomen and pelvic floor.

title: Unwind Deep-Seated Psoas Tension
description: The front of your pelvis and the back of your neck are uniquely linked. This practice focuses on unwinding deep-seated tension in your psoas, cultivating length in your spine and balance in your neck. Itâ€™s slow, deep, and all-around good. If you connect these dots, your entire body (and mind) will thank you (by feeling a little more grounded, clear and content).

title: Manage Hyper-Extension in Knees
description: Learn to manage hyper-extension in your knees by working skillfully with your feet, quadriceps and hamstrings. Explore ways to do more than simply micro-bending your knees when working with hyper-extension. In particular, this class troubleshoots some common postures that exacerbate hyper-extension such as triangle pose, pyramid pose, standing forward bends and seated forward bends. Also great if you are without hyper-extension and want to improve the alignment and strength of your legs.

title: Understanding the Role of Glutes in Backbends
description: Should you grip your glutes in backbends? No, probably not. Should you engage your glutes in backbends? Yes, definitely. Understanding the key role that the glutes play in backbends--especially bridge pose, upward-facing bow pose, and camel pose--is essential. This practice will teach you how to use your glutes and adductors to create stability, support, and integrity in all of your backbends. This understanding is key to healthy, happy backbends. Prop: 1 block

title: Hips, Shoulders & Twists Flow
description: A straight-up vinyasa sequence that focuses on twists, hip openers, and shoulder openers. It has everything you'd expect and a few things that you might not. A great class for when you want to work your entire body, but may feel like these areas need a little extra attention. Try it, you'll like it. Props Suggested: A block and a strap.

title: Deep, Cleansing Twist Practice
description: You will use the wall to create more efficient leverage and access hard-to-reach  areas in this deep, cleansing twist practice. While most twists focus on unwinding the back-body, the use of the wall will also open the front of your shoulders and chest. In preparation for these unique twists, you will do your fair share of hip-openers and just enough standing poses.

title: Reset Your Entire Body
description: This practice will reset your entire body. It's not a sweaty massacre of a flow practice, but it may be exactly what you need.  You will proceed through all of the major muscle groups of your entire body, beginning with the balls of your feet and finishing with your neck. You will unravel tension in your calves, hamstrings, quads, and hips before proceeding to your spine and shoulders, to name a few. This is a thorough, complete class that will leave you feeling more than 60-minutes better. Props Needed; Block

title: Quick Relief for Your Shoulders, Lower Back and Hips
description: A targeted practice that brings you relief where you need it most: your shoulders, lower back and hips. Using a strap to open up your shoulders, practice reclined, seated and standing postures to help shed tension and leave you feeling more comfortable. End with a forward fold in sukhasana, with an optional savasana, if you have more time. A great practice to include in your routine for creating better body awareness. Props Needed: A strap.

title: Bakasana Variations
description: Build strength with this short yet potent sequence that works your arms and core. Practice four variations of bakasana (crow) in a flow that also includes an activating navasana (boat) and lunges. Move through supine, seated and revolved crow variations before peaking with eka pada bakasana (one-footed crow).

title: Open Your Upper Body
description: A class for all the desk workers, cooks, baby holders, body workers, car commuters and just about everyone else out there! This class is designed to open your chest while strengthening your upper-back, arms and neck. Consider this your "go to" 30 minute practice for balancing your upper-body from the day-to-day challenges of the modern world. Props Suggested: A blanket, a block and a strap.

title: Awaken & Connect to Your Core
description: Are you confused when your teacher shouts "mula bandha, uddiyana bandha, jalandhara bandha" during your vinyasa or ashtanga class? Well, here is your class. It is a take on accessing your deep-internal center (aka your core) in a sometimes subtle and sometimes not subtle way. You will do a well-rounded practice, while awakening and connecting deep sensations in your body. Props Suggested: 1 or 2 blocks or small pillow.

title: Release Shoulder, Neck, and Upper Back Tension
description: This practice will help release tension in your shoulders, neck, and upper back, allowing you to feel more calm, spacious, and renewed. This is a full, accessible practice that includes standing poses, twists, and a variety of upper-back openers that will have you feeling much better. You will need access to a wall and a block (or a block substitute).

title: Ski & Snowboard Practice
description: It goes without saying that a pre and post ski/snowboard practice should unwind tension in your quads, hamstrings, outer-hips, and lower-back. This practice does exactly that. This sequence will also dive deeply into a region of the body that can easily be neglected but is just as important for these sports: the feet, ankles, and calves. If you practice these sports, you definitely need this practice.

title: Tune Up & Get Ready for Anything
description: Have you had a long work-week and are eager to set-forth on an active warrior-weekend? Need a practice to bridge the gap and prepare you for the transition? Well, you can feel free to press "play" now. Chock full of hip, hamstring, shoulder and spine work, this practice will tune you up and get you ready for just about anything. You'll need a block and a strap for this practice (or a reasonable substitute.)

title: Continuous, Rhythmic Flow for Strength
description: This continuous, rhythmic flow practice focuses on developing strength through precise, repetitive movements. You will focus all the major muscle groups of the body including the legs, hips, spine and shoulders. If you're sitting there thinking, "damn, I need to get into shape," this is a good place to start.

title: Focused Flow
description: Establish and maintain your focus with two of yoga's most potent tools: bandha and drishti. Demystify how to use bandhas and dristhi in clear, modern language with this all-around flow that will quiet your mental chatter, hone your focus and provide you with the tools to feel present. Practice a steady series of poses that includes a little of everything: sun salutations, standing poses, inversions, twists, backbends and forward folds. Conclude with savasana.

title: Honor Your Fatigue & Transcend It
description: Tired? Tired of being tired? This practice will honor your fatigue while working to transcend it.  You'll begin with soothing, head-supported forward bends in order to nurture your body. Then, you'll work to stimulate greater energy with accessible backbends before concluding in handstand (options given for students that aren't inverting).

title: Where Did the Time Go?
description: Drop in, register, and take a breath -- it's the New Year (or, any other time for that matter). If you've ever thought "wow, a whole year went by and I barely noticed it," this practice is for you. This all-around flow practice is focused on helping you practice the skill of being present. Sure, you'll stretch, strengthen, cleanse and more, but the real focus here is registering and savoring each moment.

title: Strong & Steady Flow
description: Another installment of my "continuous flow" classes also known as "Jason puts a muzzle on it and leads you through a nice, strong sequence series". It's a straight-up, reasonably paced, challenging vinyasa practice that includes plenty of salutations, strong leg-work, a bit of abs and few more offerings to round the sequence out.

title: Refine Your Handstand
description: Focus on developing greater core, arm and shoulder strength while building up to handstand. This flow practice will awaken and rejuvenate your entire body while teaching you tips to refine your handstand or approach it for the very first time. Students that are new to handstand will be given a brief tutorial on the getting into the pose while seasoned handstanders will get to bypass this tutorial and dig deeper into this pose and many others.

title: Pre/Post Surf Session
description: Focused on opening your shoulders, neck and upper-back, this practice is ideal for pre and post surfing sessions. A mellow, yet deep practice that is designed to wring out tension in your lower-back with accessible forward bends and twists. If you know that paddling for hours leaves your lower-back and upper-body worked, this practice is for you.

title: Contrarian Core
description: Inspired by the notion of "your core", evocative of much imagery, although descriptive of very little. What this class does focus on is the relationship between your inner-legs, pelvic floor, hip-flexors and abdominal center. It's like other core classes, but a bit longer and a bit more creative. Use a few of yoga's basic poses like crow, plank and chair to target these muscles in a new way. Try it out, it's pretty good (if contrarian).

title: Rhythmic Flow to Awaken & Strengthen
description: Another continuous, rhythmic breathing practice that will awaken and strengthen you entire body. This is a demanding practice that focuses on developing and sustaining a consistent breathing pattern from beginning to end. You will move dynamically for the majority of the sequence in order to establish a tempo for your breath, then settle into a few long, slow, deep holds before melting into savasana.

title: Unravel Tension in the Side Seam of Your Body
description: Focus on unraveling tension in your outer-hips, outer-legs, and side-body in this balanced vinyasa practice.  This grounding sequence offers creative ways to gain more flexibility and awareness in the side-seam of your body. It begins with slow, deep opening work before proceeding into a vigorous flow and concluding with deep side-bends such as parivritta janu sirsasana.

title: Challenging Rhythmic Flow
description: This is a big, strong, rhythmic vinyasa class that features continuous movement and accessible, yet challenging postures, especially arm balances. Back by popular demand but a slightly modified rhythmic flow class with harder postures, this is challenging practice, but not ridiculously so. Press play if you want to work your whole body, advance your practice safely and perhaps have a good laugh here and there as well.

title: Go To Hips & Spine Practice
description: Keep your hips and spine healthy, strong and mobile in a complete practice. Balance strength and flexibility in your hips and take your spine through all of its motions, forward bends, backbends, twists and side bends. Move your pelvis and spine together in all of your poses. There is plenty of time to address the  other parts of your body including your shoulders and core. Props Suggested: A block.

title: Relax Before a Stressful Event
description: Relieve anticipatory stress by grounding your nervous system and focusing your attention. Includes accessible standing postures and salutations, as well as seated forward bends. Repetitive patterning of easy to access poses cat and cow, chair, half salutations, warrior 1 and 2, wide leg forward fold and bridge.

title: Keep It Moving Whole Body Flow
description: Start with ten minutes of hip and shoulder openers before launching into several different styles of sun salutations, all of which integrate core work. To keep things moving, you'll practice a dynamic combination of standing postures, standing balances and creative transitions. Conclude your practice with inversions, backbends, forward bends, side bends and twists. A strong, balanced, all-around ninety minute class.

title: Meditation Prep
description: Open your hips, hamstrings, and groins as a preparation for seated meditation. This sequence will create more comfort in your body and prepare you to sit with greater steadiness and ease. While it includes a very brief seated meditation at the end, it is the perfect companion for a longer self-guided sit or another yogaglo class that features seated meditation.

title: Vigorous All-Around Flow
description: An all-around, vigorous practice that will strengthen and open your body while making you sweat. This sequence cuts to the chase by launching into several different types of sun-salutations before transitioning into a standing pose and core-strengthener flow.

title: Goodbye Exhaustion, Hello Energy
description: Tired, feeling blue, unenthused or downright exhausted? This practice gives into the fact that you're feeling tired and starts slowly, gently and quietly with some reclined work. Then, it builds into some effective and uncommon awakening movements that include rolling back and forth from plow pose to seated forward bends. It continues this trend by gliding you through sun-salutations, standing poses, and awakening backbends.

title: Continuous Jason Flow
description: This practice was born from the realization that students might want their teacher to close their yap once in awhile and let them drop into their own experience. So this strong, well-rounded practice is largely uninstructed. Only calls out of the poses are given, without an earful of "do this and feel that." Do a bit of everything that you'd expect in a good, satisfying flow practice including sun-salutations, standing poses, arm-balances and more.

title: 5 Minutes, 5 Salutations
description: If you only have 5 minutes to practice, you don't have much time to read a description. So, here it is. You'll do 5 different salutations in 5 minutes. You'll feel much better and happy that you pressed play.

title: Quick Snowboard Recovery
description: You probably just want to lay down after a long day of riding. However, spending a few minutes stretching your feet, calves, hamstrings, quads and hips will make you feel even better. A mellow sequence, that will help you recover and prepare for another day on the mountain or a long car ride home. As a bonus, do a few twists that will help relieve stress on your lower back.

title: Let Go of the Day's Tension, Prepare for a Calm Night
description: This soothing practice is designed to reduce the physical tension and mental stress that can accumulate during your day. It includes supported chest, spine and shoulder openers, as well as hip-openers and twists. It is remarkable how a 20-minute practice can be so effective in turning your day around and preparing you for a calm night. Props Suggested: 2 blocks

title: Upper Body Strength Flow
description: Full of interesting and satisfying upper-body strengthening postures, create greater stability and tone in your shoulders, chest, and upper-arms. Nope, it isn't full of ridiculously inaccessible level 200 postures that only acrobats can do. It is full of things that you can actually do or at least approach within reason. The practice as always is deliberate and accessible. It's hard, but in a good way. Props Needed: Two blocks and wall space.

title: Full-Circumference Hip Opening
description: Dedicated to opening the full-circumference of your hip-joints, this class will leave your hips feeling clear, spacious and balanced. So often, "hip-opening" practices focus on the back and outer-hips while neglecting the front and inner-compartments of the hips. Instead, practice lunges, standing poses, and other hip-opening postures that will dig deep into your hip-flexors and adductors as well as the outer and back portions of your hips.

title: Open Your Hamstrings
description: This practice focuses on using the leverage of the hip-flexors and abdominals to fold you body more deeply into forward bends. With a soothing start that stretches your hamstrings and hips, this practice proceeds to awaken your abdominals, hip-flexors, and quads. It continues with salutations and standing forward bends and concludes with seated forward bends. Expect to open your hamstrings and learn the hinging action of your front body.

title: Quick Hip Openers
description: Quick and to the point, unwind tension in all of the muscles that comprise your hip joint. Use this practice by itself when you have limited time or include it prior to another practice to give your hips a little more time to open up.

title: A Complete Flow to Get You Through Your Week
description: A complete practice designed to anchor your week by challenging and balancing your body. Work on creative sun salutation flows, incorporate core work throughout and explore handstand and arm balance options. Close your practice with backbends, followed by quieting forward bends, twists and side-bends. Rest in savasana and feel energized and focused. Props Suggested: A block and a strap.

title: Headstand Tutorial
description: It is essential to learn headstand from an experienced, qualified yoga teacher that can see your body and give you direct feedback. Therefore, this tutorial is only designed to supplement your practice and education. Also, due to the impractical nature of watching this tutorial while actually doing this particular pose, I recommend that you bake some cookies, grab some warm almond milk, and watch this tutorial rather than throwing yourself aloft. Then, allow sometime for the cookies, milk, and information to digest before practicing. Enjoy.

title: Sun Salutation Flow
description: Designed for level 1 students looking for an accessible challenge that will deepen your practice, this will guide you through sun-salutations, lunges and standing poses. It will help synchronize your breath with movement, open and strengthen your legs, and cultivate greater vitality in your entire body. This sequence will also teach you the most effective way to of step forward into lunges from down-dog when practicing sun salutations.

title: Chatturanga and Up Dog Tutorial
description: Most students have a significant gap in their education when it comes to chatturanga and up-dog. Although these poses form the backbone of vinyasa yoga, they are rarely taught. This tutorial is designed to help you practice these poses more safely, slowly and patiently. Yes, these poses require strength, but, even more, they require understanding. If possible, I encourage you to watch this tutorial once, then watch it a second time and practice along.

title: Practice for Shoulders, Neck and Upper Back
description: This practice focuses on gently stretching your shoulders, neck, and upper-back. It is designed to soothe your nerves and restore greater alignment, vitality and comfort to your upper-body. While the sequence covers a wide-range of poses, it emphasizes seated shoulder openers, seated twists, and standing poses.

title: Strong Shoulder, Hip & Groin Flow
description: Back by popular demand, another strong vinyasa sequence that contains infinitely more quiet than instructions. Poses are called out, allowing you to drop into your own experience with minimal instruction. This round emphasizes deep shoulder, hip and groin opening that will leave you feeling grounded and content. You can choose to savor the quiet, create your own play-list, or listen to a baseball game in the background.

title: The Power of Your Breath
description: Your biggest ally is your breath. You will focus on developing its depth, rhythm, efficiency in this slow, strong, and steady vinyasa practice. You'll practice using the breath to unblock restrictions and set a sustainable tone in this complete practice. You will leave feeling calm, grounded, and content.

title: Vinyasa Yoga Tutorial
description: Ever wonder: How do you make that whispery sound with your breath--and, why? How do you get your foot all the way between your hands when stepping forward from down-dog? How do you figure out if you're moving too slow or your teacher is just plain insane for having you move so fast? Yep, you've probably had these questions and more. If you want to understand vinyasa yoga more skillfully, here's your vid!

title: Active Recovery for Athletes
description: "Don't forget to stretch." We've heard it before but often forget to follow through. This class is a combination of active recovery and relaxation that leaves your hips, quads, spine, and shoulders begging you to come back again, and again. Learn how to recover from any high-intensity training like HIIT, strength exercises, or sports activities. Begin by warming up with foam rolling, then move into shoulder stretches, lunges, and side body work. Wind down with Pigeon, Gecko, Book-Opening Twist, and Sports Center Watching Pose—yes, you read that right. Rejuvenate your mind and muscles to bounce back faster tomorrow. Props Needed: Foam roller or lacrosse balls. Props Suggested: A wall.

title: Bakasana Tutorial
description: Students (including yours truly) often approach difficult poses by simply working hard. While hard work is often required, postures are much, much easier when you actually understand them. This practice will teach you the main actions of bakasana and guide you into this essential pose in a smart, effective, accessible sequence.

title: Nurturing Flow for Life Transitions
description: Calibrated to restore your energy, calm your nerves, and support your immune system. Nurture your body and mind as you transition from one season to another. This slow, deeply grounding sequence contains head-supported forward bends, restorative postures with minimal props required, and inversions. It's just the thing you need when you want a complete practice but don't have any energy to spare.

title: Quick Shoulder and Chest Openers
description: Quick and to the point, this short practice will help you unwind tension in your shoulders and chest. Do this quick practice when you have limited time, especially when you've been traveling or sitting at a desk all day or include it prior to another practice when your upper body needs a little more TLC. Props Needed: A strap.

title: Reverse Energizing Flow
description: You're interested in an "energizing" sequence because you're tired, right? And, when you're tired you want to rest -- but if you rest too long you feel lousy. Right? Think about this class as a class in reverse. You will give in to your fatigue and start in savasana. Then, you'll coax yourself into some reclined twists, slow lunges, and even some standing poses. To complete the practice you will do several rounds of sun-salutations and finish in a brief standing meditation. It'll open your eyes and get you moving.

title: Melodic, Quieting Evening Flow
description: This practice contains just enough fluid movement to wipe away stress and revitalize the body without being over stimulating or fatiguing. You will start slowly, by opening the hips and hamstrings before moving into a slow-flow sequence of lunges, twists, forward bends and side-bends.

title: Building an Efficient Practice
description: Using props to enhance the efficiency of your practice isn't cheating -- it's smart. That said, "the cheater's series" has more ring to it than "the smart series." Whatever we call it, this practice is designed to maximize your comfort and depth in backbends while minimizing your output by using a few well-placed props. In particular, you will explore new ways of doing cobra, up-dog, bow, bridge, upward-facing bow. Try it, you'll like it (unless you're an extreme rugged-individualist type, in which case you're more than welcome to make things harder on yourself than you need to).

title: Release Quad, Hip and Shoulder Tension
description: Stretch your quads, lengthen your hip-flexors, and open your shoulders in this demanding, yet accessible practice. This sequence will teach you several uncommon, effective ways to release tension from these regions while guiding you into pigeon pose 2 (eka pada rajakapotasana 2). This sequence also includes a handful of sun-salutations and a few backbends.

title: Hanumanasana Sequence
description: Whether you love it, hate it, or have achieved some sort of equinamous relationship with it, you should dive into this hanumanasana sequence. Why? 1) It will open your hips and hamstrings; 2) It will coach you through subtle nuances of the pose; 3) You'll explore a bigger, broader picture of "the splits" by learning to spread your attention evenly into all poses; 4) You'll probably like it even when you're not liking it; 5) It's only 45 minutes.

title: Lotus Pose Tutorial: Part Two
description: The second episode of our 4-part practice and tutorial dedicated to developing lotus pose (padmasana). In this segment you will prepare for lotus by focusing on opening your outer-hips and deep hip-rotators. You will also learn a second way to approach folding your legs into lotus. And, again, you will work on a few relevant standing poses, open your inner-groins, and drop into a few sun salutations (I even sneak a couple of mellow backbends into this one!)

title: Lotus Pose Tutorial: Part One
description: The first episode of our 4-part practice and tutorial dedicated to developing lotus pose (padmasana). You will emphasize opening your inner-groins and learn how to fold your legs into lotus with greater safety, comfort and skill (read, your knees will probably be much, much happier with this approach). Of course, you will also open your outer-hips and glide through a couple of sun-salutations and relevant standing poses.

title: Lotus Pose Tutorial: Part Three
description: The third episode of our 4-part practice and tutorial dedicated to developing lotus pose (padmasana). In this practice you will prepare for lotus with a combination of outer-hip and inner-groin opening. And, here's how this practice is significantly different from episodes 1 and 2: you will do quite a bit of deep opening while laying on your back. You will develop an even more refined understanding of the neuro-muscular pattern of lotus by working on folding your legs without using your hands. A third method of coming into lotus is presented.

title: No-Nonsense Core Flow
description: Enjoy this straight-forward, no-nonsense practice that focuses on your core. Well, enjoy might not be the right word to use for it but, not every moment needs to be hedonistic. You will not do 1,000 crunches (fortunately), but you will engage your abdominals and hip-flexors in plenty of creative, effective ways.

title: Lotus Pose Tutorial: Part Four
description: The last episode of our 4-part practice and tutorial dedicated to developing lotus pose (padmasana). Now that you've developed steadiness and ease in lotus, what's next (other than sitting quietly, of course)? This sequence is your answer. After practicing several deep hip and groin openers you will transition into a series of half and full-lotus variations, including lotus in handstand.

title: Slow Burn
description: This practice will strengthen your entire body, open your hips and shoulders and balance your nervous system. You will focus on slow, deliberate transitions between postures and long, demanding holds. This challenging, yet accessible practice will reconnect you to the essence of your practice by helping you focus on breathing into your body and moving at a mindful, consistent pace. Postures from every asana category are included. Prop Suggested: A wall.

title: Get Grounded When Deeply Fatigued & Depleted
description: Got stress? Got a cold? So stressed that you got a cold? This practice will treat you well if you are struggling with either or both. Designed to be practiced when you are feeling depleted, this practice is mellow, grounding, and soothing. It will patiently open your body, encourage circulation in your upper-extremities and allow you to move deliberately even when you are deeply fatigued. Use this practice to feel good. Props Needed: A blanket, a bolster and a strap. Props Suggested: Wall space.

title: Deep, Spacious Backbends
description: Want deep, spacious backbends that leave you feeling grounded, clear and content? Yep, me too. This sequence will prepare your thighs, shoulders, and spine for urdhva dhanurasana (upward-facing bow pose) and viparita dandasana (inverted staff pose). You'll get a great practice and refine your understanding of these essential postures. This practice was inspired by everyone who gave me feedback that they want to build on the level 1/2 backbend practice by adding a little more vim and vigor.

title: Unravel Tension with Twists
description: This practice is designed for those that find twisting to be an effective, satisfying way to unravel tension in their spine, shoulders and outer-hips. The practice includes a nice sequence of standing poses and hip-openers before transitioning into deep seated-twists. You will emphasize axial extension (making your spine longer) and rotating from your back body instead of your abdominals. You'll feel good and clear afterward.

title: Strength and Stamina for New Year
description: Do you want to start the New Year by cultivating strength and stamina in your body, while also committing to a practice of seated meditation? If so, here's your practice! This vigorous morning sequence will lead you through 4 different types of sun salutations before guiding you through a wide-array of standing poses. Toss in an inversion, some hip-opening, twisting and mild-backbending before a 5-minute seated meditation and you have the formula for this nourishing, balanced practice.

title: Shoulders, Hips and Breath
description: You'll open your shoulders, you'll open your hips, and you'll breathe. This is like saying "flour, butter, and sugar." Sure, they're all allergens to most bodies, but it sounds good, right? Move through an accessible practice that coaches your body through challenging asanas in a safe and slow way. Expect to work hard, but also know that it will be delicious and satisfying.

title: Bird of Paradise Practice
description: Like many of my YogaGlo classes, this practice for Bird of Paradise and compass pose comes from a request. Truthfully, though, I happen to love teaching these poses because there is so much to work with: The opening of the hamstrings, inner-legs, and outer hips; the dynamics of sidebending; the deep rotation and binding of the arms; and the subtle play of balancing.

title: Ten Postures, Ten Minutes
description: If you only have ten minutes, this is your practice. You'll do ten postures in ten minutes -- just enough time to release tension in your hips, hamstrings, shoulders and spine. You'll also balance and reset your energy by including one inversion or inversion alternative. This class will leave you feeling more calm, focused and content. Prop Suggested: Wall space.

title: Evening Yoga Routine
description: Unwind your hips, hamstrings, and lower back after a long day. This evening sequence starts with reclined postures that will allow you to relax your mind and stretch your legs. It transitions to several long, slow, deep hip-openers, twists, and forward bends. Expect to let go of stress and prepare for a quiet night.

title: Yoga for Travel
description: When I get off a plane or out of a car, I want to do 3 things: open my hips, fix my back and appreciate that I'm at my destination. This is a go-to practice to re-balance your body. It has just enough movement and strength to make you feel alive, manage your jet-lag, and help reboot your system.

title: Maintain a Healthy Back
description: A practice designed to provide relief for mild, non-acute back-pain. The sequence emphasizes keeping a neutral position in your back and pelvis while encouraging your legs and hips to move through their full range of motion. Encourage circulation and breath in your lower back while minimizing movements that may agitate your back. Elongate your spine and release tension in your back-body. Great as a regular practice to maintain a healthy, comfortable back for those that are prone to this type of discomfort. Props Needed: A chair, a strap and a blanket.

title: Release Spine Tension
description: Target those tight, achy spots in your back with a full complement of twists, sidebends and backbends. Learn how subtle-shifts of awareness and action in your practice can leave your spine feeling tension-free. In addition to sun-salutations and standing poses, practice several uncommon twists that are sure to become staples in your routine. Finish this revitalizing practice with several upward-facing bow poses and counter poses.

title: Embrace the Meditative Aspects of Vinyasa Practice
description: Experience how a subtle, mindful approach to vinyasa can deepen your practice, reduce stress, and soothe your nervous system. Some of the focal points in this practice will be the lengthening of your exhalation, the relaxation of your sensory organs, and the continuous awareness of rooting downward into the floor.

title: Open, Strengthen, Balance Your Body
description: This is a full, classic yoga practice that will open, strengthen and balance your body. Accessible for newer students and thorough enough for seasoned practitioners, this practice will awaken your body and balance your energy. This practice includes every posture category in balanced doses. It includes hip and shoulder openers, accessible core-strengtheners, salutations, standing postures, inversions and more. If you're craving a complete, deep, unrushed practice you've found the right class. Props Suggested: A block and wall space.

title: Align & Refine Yoga Postures
description:
Aligning and refining your standing postures
This sequence will strengthen your thighs, stretch your inner-legs, and improve your understanding of warrior 2 (Virabhadrasana 2) and it's colleagues, triangle pose (Utthitta Trikonasana) and side-angle pose (Utthitta Parsvakonasana). This thorough practice will not only leave you feeling better, it will refine your understanding of how to align your hips in these essential postures.

title: Morning Yoga Practice
description: Do you spring out of bed first thing in the morning and launch into Sun Salutation after Sun Salutation? No? Us neither. Do you need to slowly unravel and untangle before your first Chaturanga? Yep, us too. This practice will help ease you out of bed in the morning with hip, torso, and shoulder openers. Then, it will awaken your entire body by leading you into moderately paced Sun Salutations and standing poses. Think, a good, reasonable way to wake up and feel much better for the rest of the day.

title: Unwind Back Tension
description: This vinyasa practice will help unwind tension from your back. The continuous, reasonable pace of the practice...not too fast, not too slow...will keep you moving, yet allow each pose to be completely developed. You'll do about 40 minutes of various twists before transitioning into a progressive sequence of backbends. You'll feel cleansed and light after savasana.

title: Core Strengthening Practice
description: You will awaken, strengthen and integrate your core in this practice. You won't do 10,000 sit-ups or crunches. Instead, you'll examine how your feet, legs and abdominals work together to create greater strength, integration and depth in all of your poses. You can expect plenty of abdominal work woven into sun salutations, standing poses, forward bends and twists.

title: Sun Salutation Series
description: Develop strength and cultivate mindfulness in this slow, strong flow. This practice emphasizes moving slowly, holding postures, and, more interestingly, spending more time in the transitional spaces between each posture. This practice will clearly articulate the intense demand of not rushing between the poses. You'll do plenty of standing poses and work on the space between them, hold Chaturanga for longer than usual, and do a couple of arm balances and a few other things to round out the sequence. Push play now.

title: Non-Stop Flow for Core and Legs
description: This class is light on guided instruction, storytelling and overall teacher chit chat. Instead, it is (as the title implies) a nonstop flow, from beginning to end. This will open, strengthen and move your entire body in a steady, yet reasonably paced practice. Not super fast, but definitely not slow. It's that "I need a bit of everything in 60-minutes" class that will leave you feeling pretty good, mentally and physically.

title: Mindful Flow
description: This complete vinyasa practice begins with slow, deep hip-openers before progressing to a steady, continuous stream of standing pose variations. The practice also includes inversions, backbends and mind-settling forward bends. This practice will stretch and strengthen your entire body, and help you be more mindful of the quiet stillness between your postures. Prop Suggested: Block

title: Strong, Mindful Stamina Flow
description: This is a strong, mindful practice that will develop greater strength and stamina in your legs and core. The key to this practice isn't just the sun salutations, the standing poses, or the uncommon abdominal work, it is the pace and repetition of the sequence. This practice produces strength by asking you to move slowly and deliberately in the transitions between the poses. Still deciding? Just press play.

title: Deeper Backbends, Greater Comfort
description: This backbend practice is designed to make dhanurasana (bow) and urdhva dhanurasana (upward-facing bow) more accessible and comfortable. It includes plenty of thigh openers, some nice twists, and relevant shoulder work. Hopefully, you'll do it, like it, repeat it, tell your friends about it, have your friends tell their friends, and we'll have a mass movement of reasonably comfortable backbends.

title: Binding
description: Think your arms are too short to do bindings? Well, friends, it's time to bid that excuse good-bye. This thorough, vinyasa practice will teach you the mechanics of binding while preparing your shoulders, hips and spine for it adequately. You'll wring your entire body, learn how to make binding more accessible and feel like a million bucks afterward.

title: Open Shoulders and Restore Upper Body Balance
description: This sequence focuses on opening your shoulders and restoring balance to your upper-body. You will practice an intelligent sequence of sun salutations, thigh-openers, and standing poses while incorporating new ways of opening and aligning your shoulders.

title: Hatha For Backbends
description: A practice designed to help you fall in love with backbends, or at least come to terms with them, by focusing on the actions that will lengthen your spine, strengthen your back, and decompress your lower back. This class features Locust Pose (Salabhasana), Cobra Pose (Bhujangasana), and Upward Facing Dog. Open your thighs, strengthen your back, and (maybe, just maybe) learn a thing or two about back bending with greater comfort.

title: Refine Your Standing Balances
description: Afraid you're going to fall over and take out a row of fellow students while in tree pose? Fear not. This thorough practice will refine all of your standing balances and help you stay centered. You will focus on developing strength, flexibility, and poise while practicing Tree Pose (Vrksasana), Half Moon Pose (Ardha Chandrasana), Eagle Pose (Garudasana), Warrior III (Virabhadrasana III), and many more.

title: Yoga to Release Tension
description: If you like having dessert first, press the play button pronto. This practice bypasses the hustle of chatturanga updog downdog and settles into a deep-practice of unraveling tension from the side-body and outer-hips. You will focus on building up to revolved head-to-knee pose (parivritta janu sirsasana) and revolved open-angle pose (parivritta upa vista konasana). You willâ€”guaranteedâ€”leave feeling clearer and more content.

title: Open Your Hips, Wring Out Your Spine
description: Experience a balance of power, precision and mindfulness in this complete vinyasa practice. You will focus on opening your outer hips, releasing tension in your spine and maintaining a steady rhythm of movement. Start in timed hip-opening postures before proceeding to standing twists and concluding with a few challenging arm-balances before hitting the floor to cool down. Prop Suggested: A block

title: Hip Opening & Abdominal Strengthening
description: Opening your hips and strengthening your abdominals pair so well with each other. This long, slow, deep practice of hip-opening and abdominal strengthening takes an unhurried approach through reclined, seated and standing postures. It includes plenty of movement and can be pretty intense in its own way. You will arrive at lotus and a few arm-balances (of course options are given for those of you that need them) before cooling down and savasana.

title: Complete & Balanced Practice
description: This is a big, thorough, reasonably paced class that includes just about everything. It opens with hip-opening lunges, proceeds to a bunch of different types of salutations, then transitions to standing poses, backbends, forward bends and shoulder-openers. If you want an all-around class that will leave you feeling grounded, clear and content, this is for you. Prop: Block

title: Jumping Back
description: The common assumption is that jumping back to chaturanga is safer than jumping back to plank. In this discussion, Jason outlines the biomechanics of jumping back to both poses and shows that they are equally safe if done well.

title: Meditation For Resilience
description: This meditation helps you embody resilience while creating space for self-reflection. Follow a grounding body scan to awaken your awareness, then focus on letting go of excess with your exhale. This class was previously aired on May 21, 2021 as part of a 10-day meditation challenge.

title: Demystifying Mula Bandha
description: Learn about the subtle and gross anatomy of the yogic action, mula bandha. Examine it from both a historical and contemporary perspective, keeping in mind that there is no such thing as a "mula bandha muscle."

title: Rest Your Body, Soothe Your Mind
description: A deep, quieting, nurturing restorative practice designed to rest your body and soothe your mind. Props needed: Two blankets, a belt and a bolster

title: Rhythmic, Continuous Vinyasa
description: This is Jason's most rhythmic, continuous vinyasa practice to date. The sole focus is using movement to establish a smooth, consistent breathing pattern from beginning to end. Its a deep, demanding, meditative practice that will have you prioritizing your breath and dropping all other thoughts and concerns.

title: Twist Tutorial
description: Make sure that you are getting the most from this all-levels, utilitarian twist. This tutorial will prepare your hips before showing you the optimal alignment, pelvic position and various arm-positions needed to maximize this posture's benefits.

title: Challenge Your Body, Settle Your Mind
description: Once you develop a consistent flow of breath, you'll be challenged to sustain it with various standing balances and arm-balances. A continuous, rhythmic vinyasa, this practice will have you breathing smoothly and steadily from beginning to end. Challenge your body, nurture your breath, and settle your mind.

title: Ujjayi Breath Tutorial
description: This tutorial breaks explores "ujjayi" breath--the most commonly practiced method of breathing in contemporary hatha and vinyasa yoga. You will learn how to regulate the sound of the breath along with it's texture and volume. An absolute essential tutorial for all yoga practitioners.

title: Rhythmic Flow
description: First and foremost, this is an all-around, mindfully-paced vinyasa practice that includes sun salutations, standing poses, twists, backbends, and forward bends. Itâ€™s a consistent, rhythmic practice that Iâ€™m pretty sure youâ€™ll like. Within this framework, you will emphasize unwinding your hip-flexors, balancing your neck, and understanding the relationship between the pelvis and skull. NOT GREAT CONTENT IF YOU'RE PREGNANT.

title: All Around Go-To Practice
description: Designed to be your go-to practices for an all-around sequence, this class will open your body and settle your mind. Continuous, fluid, and dynamic (yet, absolutely un-rushed), this sequence explores the topic of presence, awareness and mindfulness. By noticing the details of your body--such as your breath, pulse, temperature and subtle energy--you will cultivate moment-to-moment awareness that will enhance your practice in every way.

title: Five Minutes to Maui
description: Press play if you want to do one pose for five minutes and experience an instant vacation. This simple, deeply relaxing version of savasana will relax your lower back, open your chest and restore your legs. A chair and 2 or 3 blankets will really make this class feel like a sweet mini vacation. Props Needed: A chair and two blankets.

title: Deep Relaxation Practice
description: Cultivate deep relaxation within reclined breath awareness and pranayama practice. Designed to soothe your nervous system, quiet your mind and make your breathing more efficient. Become aware of your unconscious breathing patterns and learn to optimize your breath in a mindful way.

title: Arm Balance Workshop
description: This fun, challenging sequence of arm-balances is designed to teach you how to do arm-balances with greater mindfulness and ease. Students often over-rely on force when working on these poses rather than learning to understand the essential actions and movements. This sequence will help your body understand the mechanics and leverage of arm-balances and make these inspiring poses part of your repertoire.

title: Pincha Mayurasana Tutorial
description: This tutorial provides you with a clear understanding of how to approach and practice forearm balance (pincha mayurasana). It begins with a few simple preparatory steps before showing the most effective way to place your hands, use a block and transition into the pose. It continues, by giving you some of the key instructions for practicing the posture.

title: Stressful Day?
description: This soothing practice is designed to calm your nervous system and decrease stimulation. It is full of quieting forward bends, gentle twists, and breath awareness. This is the perfect antidote to a long, stressful day. This sequence can also be used to support your body when you are facing stress, fatigue, illness, and travel.

title: Yoga Flow for Strength
description: Paced to keep you moving without rushing you along, this is a deliberately organized sequence that will strengthen the major muscle groups of your body without sacrificing attention to detail. Although challenging, focus on poses that most students can actually do (or approach within reason) and repeat. After-all, if you can't do or repeat the poses, it's pretty hard to develop significant strength with them.

title: Deepen Your Yoga Practice
description: This is a straightforward, well-rounded, thoroughly satisfying practice. You will practice a wide range of hip-openers, Sun Salutations, standing poses, twists, backbends, forward bends, and inversions while you deepen your knowledge of yoga — exactly what you came here for.

title: Slow Deep Strong Flow Practice
description: This practice will open your inner-legs and outer hips while preparing you for a 10 minute seated meditation and deep savasana at the end of class. Begin your practice by moving slowly and deeply, while exploring the subtle, meditative aspects of vinyasa yoga through strength of your body and consistency in your breath.

title: 5 Minute Yoga Break at Your Desk
description: Only have time for a 5 minute yoga-break? This chair-based practice will help open your shoulders and spine while bringing greater circulation to your entire upper-body. This simple, accessible practice is also appropriate for students that need a gentle, highly-supported sequence.

title: Five Minute Yoga Break in Your Chair
description: Only have time for a 5 minute yoga-break? This chair-based practice will help open your hips and hamstrings while bringing circulation to your entire lower-body. This simple, accessible practice is also appropriate for students that need a gentle, highly-supported sequence.

title: Get Into Your Comfort Zone
description: This simple breathing practice can help calm your nerves, ground your body, and relax your mind. Begin with a moment of guided relaxation followed by breathwork that uses lengthened exhalations to achieve a deep sense of comfort and calm.

title: Yoga for Sleeplessness
description: The frustration and fatigue of insomnia are incredibly challenging. This restorative sequence is designed to help you manage the effects of a sleepless night and cultivate relaxation. Practice it after a difficult night to help reduce the ragged experience of sleeplessness, before going to bed to help reduce stress, or anytime you just need to unwind.

title: 5 Important Tips for Beginners
description: Starting a yoga practice is exciting, but it can also be confusing. In this talk, Jason discusses five important things beginners should keep in mind, based on over 20 years of teaching experience.

title: Pranayama and Seated Meditation
description:
This practice will invoke deep relaxation and ground your nerves. You'll begin with a reclined mindfulness meditation and progress into a soothing pranayama practice. You'll continue with a brief seated pranayama practice and conclude with seated meditation.
Props Recommended: two blankets, one block

title: Guided Savasana
description: You'll be guided into deep relaxation and subtle awareness in this led savasana practice. Containing a balanced ratio of verbal cueing and silence, this practice can stand alone or be paired with any other YogaGlo offering. It will take you deeply inward and allow you to let go into a feeling of spacious restfulness.
